svo.explanation: English follows SVO (Subject-Verb-Object) order strictly, while Chinese may place time expressions between subject and verb.
svo.example: I eat apples → 我吃苹果

verbTense.explanation: English verbs change form to show time (present, past, future), while Chinese uses time words without changing the verb.
verbTense.example: I ate (past) vs. I eat (present) → 我吃了 vs. 我吃

articles.explanation: English uses articles before nouns, which do not exist in Chinese.

wordOrder.explanation: English uses SVO while Korean uses SOV (Subject-Object-Verb) order.
wordOrder.example: I love you (SVO) → 나는 너를 사랑해요 (SOV)

auxiliary.explanation: English uses helping verbs (am, is, are, do, does) which Korean expresses through verb endings.
auxiliary.example: I am eating → 나는 먹고 있어요

particles.explanation: English uses prepositions before nouns, while Korean uses particles after nouns.

wordOrder.explanation: Both English and Thai use SVO order, making basic sentences similar in structure.
wordOrder.example: I eat rice → ฉันกินข้าว

verbForm.explanation: English changes verb forms for tense, while Thai adds time words without changing the verb.
verbForm.example: I went → ฉันไป (with time context)

articles.explanation: English uses articles (a, an, the) while Thai does not require them.

analysis.notAvailable: Sentence structure analysis not available for this language pair.
